facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 196 of 1964 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 196 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 8, 1954 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 111 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 8, 1954, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 1 1 1 of 1948.

facts.text: Nursingdas Seal owned garden land measuring 31 bighas known as premises Nos. 26, 27 and 28, Dum Dum Cossipore Road, Ghooghoodanga.

anchor.surface_text: Nursingdas Seal was the owner of garden land measuring 31 bighas and known as premises Nos. 26, 27 and 28, Dum Dum Cossipore Road, Ghooghoodanga.

facts.text: Nursingdas Seal died in December 1888.

anchor.surface_text: He died in December, 1888, leaving a will dated December 11, 1888 whereby he appointed his widow, Sukheswari, as the executrix

facts.text: Nursingdas Seal left a will dated December 11, 1888 appointing Sukheswari as executrix and bequeathing estate to her for life then to son Nilakantha absolutely.

anchor.surface_text: leaving a will dated December 11, 1888 whereby he appointed his widow, Sukheswari, as the executrix and bequeathed his estate to Sukheswari for her natural life and thereafter to his son, Nilakantha absolutely by way of vested remainder.

facts.text: Sewdas Mobata purchased Nilkantha's interest in garden lands at auction sale on September 9, 1899 in execution of decree for mortgage dated September 7, 1893 executed by Nilkantha.

anchor.surface_text: On September 9, 1899 one Sewdas Mobata purchased the interest of Nilkantha in the garden lands at an auction sale held in execution of a decree passed in a suit to enforce a mortgage dated September 7, 1893 executed by Nilkantha.

facts.text: Nilkantha became insolvent and his estate vested in Official Assignee of Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: Nilkantha became an insolvent and his estate vested in the Official Assignee of Bengal.

facts.text: Sewdas title confirmed by compromise decree dated February 17, 1904 in Suit No. 595 of 1901.

anchor.surface_text: Sewdass title to the property subject to the life interest of Sukheswari was confirmed by a compromise decree dated February 17, 1904 passed in Suit No. 595 of 1901

facts.text: Conveyance dated August 17, 1904 executed by Sukheswari and Official Assignee of Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: and a conveyance dated August 17, 1904 executed by Sukheswari and the Official Assignee of Bengal as the assignee of the estate of Nilkantha.

facts.text: Sukheswari died on April 20, 1933.

anchor.surface_text: On April 20, 1933, Sukheswari died.

facts.text: Title of Sewdas to the property devolved on the plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: The title of Sewdas to the property subsequently devolved on the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Upendra Nath Addey obtained Mourashi Mokrari lease of 6 bighas from Sukheswari on July 30, 1901 for Rs. 1,300 salami.

anchor.surface_text: On July 30, 1901 one Upendra Nath Addey obtained from Sukheswari a Mourashi Mokrari lease of 6 bighas out of the aforesaid 31 bighas of garden land on payment of Rs. 1,300/- by way of salami or premium.

facts.text: Leased property comprised in C.S. Dags Nos. 144-150.

anchor.surface_text: The leased property is comprised in C.S. Dags Nos. 144-150.

facts.text: Lease executed pursuant to decree dated September 2, 1899 in suit for specific performance of agreement executed in or about 1891.

anchor.surface_text: The lease was executed by Sukheswari in pursuance of a decree passed against her on September 2, 1899, in a suit for specific performance of an agreement executed by her in or about 1891.

facts.text: Leasehold interest of Upendra Nath vested in third defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The leasehold interest of Upendra Nath became subsequently vested in the third defendant.

facts.text: Plaintiffs instituted suit on September 15, 1945 claiming declaration of title and khas possession of garden lands.

anchor.surface_text: On September 15, 1945, the plaintiffs instituted the present suit claiming a declaration of their title and recovery of khas possession of the garden lands and for other reliefs.

facts.text: Trial Court decreed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court decreed the suit.

facts.text: High Court confirmed decree against defendants other than third defendant, now final.

anchor.surface_text: The decree passed against the defendants other than the third defendant was confirmed by the High Court, and has now become final.

facts.text: In third defendant's appeal, High Court confirmed plaintiffs' title to 6 bighas but set aside possession decree and passed decree for 3 years rent.

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal filed by the third defendant, the High Court confirmed the decree of the trial Court declaring the plaintiffs title to 6 bighas of land comprised in C.S. Dags Nos. 144-150, but it set aside the decree for recovery of khas possession and mesne profits, and instead passed a decree for 3 years rent in respect of the property.

facts.text: If Sukheswari had power to lease the property, plaintiffs cannot recover khas possession from third defendant - not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: If Sukheswari had power to lease C.S. Dags Nos. 144 to 150 to Upendra Nath Addy, it is not disputed that the plaintiffs cannot recover khas possession of the property from the third defendant this suit

facts.text: Plaintiffs contended Sukheswari had no power to grant the lease due to restriction in clause 4 of the will.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the plaintiffs, however, submitted that Sukheswari had no power to grant the lease. This contention was accepted by the trial Court, but it was rejected by the High Court

facts.text: Trial Court accepted contention that Sukheswari had no power to lease.

anchor.surface_text: This contention was accepted by the trial Court, but it was rejected by the High Court

facts.text: High Court rejected contention that Sukheswari had no power to lease.

anchor.surface_text: but it was rejected by the High Court

facts.text: Clause 4 of will authorised Sukheswari to sell portion of estate for marriages of Nilkantha and sister.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be noticed that clause 4 of the will authorised Sukheswari to sell a portion of the estate for meeting the expenses of the marriages of Nilkantha and his sister.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds clause 4 did not impose restriction on executrix power to lease under s.90 Probate Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, clause 4 of the will of Nursingdas did not impose any restriction on the power of the executrix to lease the property in due course of administration.
Under s. 90 of the Probate and Administration Act, 1881  Act No. 5 of 1881 , Sukheswari had power to lease the property unless this power was restricted by Nursingdass will.

issues.text: whether the will of Nursingdas Seal imposed any restriction on the power of the executrix appointed by the will to dispose of his immovable properties vested in her as the executrix

anchor.surface_text: The only question arising in this certificates appeal is whether the will of Nursingdas Seat imposed any restriction on the power of the executrix appointed by the will to dispose of his immovable properties vested in her as the executrix.

issues.text: whether cl. 4 of the will imposed such a restriction

anchor.surface_text: Counsel submitted that cl. 4 of the will imposed such a restriction. The operative part of the will companysisted of five clauses, which were in these terms I appoint my wife Sm. Sooleswari alias Begum as the Executrix.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant submitted that the specific authority in clause 4 to deal with the estate in a particular way negatived any authority to deal with it in other ways. We are unable to accept this contention.

arguments.court_reasoning: Clause 4 did not fetter the power even assuming purpose was marriage expenses; clear language required to restrict s.90 power

arguments.claim: Under s.90 Probate and Administration Act, Sukheswari had power to lease unless restricted by will

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 90 of the Probate and Administration Act, 1881 Act No. 5 of 1881 , Sukheswari had power to lease the property unless this power was restricted by Nursingdass will.

arguments.claim: Clause 4 authorizes sale for marriages but is not a general restriction on disposal powers

anchor.surface_text: It is to be noticed that clause 4 of the will authorised Sukheswari to sell a portion of the estate for meeting the expenses of the marriages of Nilkantha and his sister.

arguments.claim: Testator could not have intended restrictions on disposal for debts and maintenance

anchor.surface_text: Clause 5 directed the executrix to pay the testators debts. Clause 3 directed her to pay maintenance to the mother and stepmother of the testator. The testator could not have intended to impose any restriction on the power of the executrix to dispose of the estate for the payment of the debts and the maintenance.

arguments.claim: Clear language required in will to restrict executrix power under s.90

anchor.surface_text: Clear language was required for restricting the power of the executrix to deal with the property under s. 90 1 of the Probate and Administration Act, 1881.

arguments.claim: No provision in will on leasing power, so expressum facit cessare tacitum has no application

anchor.surface_text: The will contained no such language. There was no provision in the will with regard to the power of the executrix to lease the property and the principle expressum facit cessare tacitum has noapplication.

arguments.claim: Express power to sell does not restrict power to mortgage under s.90 (following Purna Chandra Bakshi v. Nobin Chandra)

anchor.surface_text: In Purna Chandra Bakshi v. Nobin Chandra Gangopadhya the Calcutta High Court held that a provision in a will authorising the executor to sell the testators property to pay off his debts could not be regarded as an implied prohibition against mortgaging the property.

holdings.text: clause 4 of the will of Nursingdas did not impose any restriction on the power of the executrix to lease the property in due course of administration

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, clause 4 of the will of Nursingdas did not impose any restriction on the power of the executrix to lease the property in due course of administration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.90 Probate Act grants power to lease unless clearly restricted by will; cl.4 authorizes sale for marriages but not general restriction; no clear language restricting lease; harmonized with cl.3,5 powers; precedent supports no implied prohibition

holdings.text: The lease is binding on the plaintiffs, and they cannot recover khas possession of the property in this suit

anchor.surface_text: The lease is binding on the plaintiff-,, and they cannot recover khas possession of the property in this suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sukheswari had power to lease under s.90 unrestricted by will; leasehold validly devolved to third defendant

holdings.text: Clear language was required for restricting the power of the executrix to deal with the property under s. 90 of the Probate and Administration Act, 1881

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory power under s.90 requires explicit restriction in will; cl.4 lacks such language
